div.head: A Chronological Table, Relating to the affairs of the CHURCH IN THE Fourth Century.

row.cell: Roman Emperours.
Ecclesiastical Affairs.
Peter made Bishop of Alexandria upon the death of Theonas.

cell.p: Diocletian triumphs at Rome for his victory over the Persians.
The Christians at Rome severely treated.

row.cell: Diocletian returns to Nicomedia, and consults with Galerius about persecuting the Christians.
The Dioeletian persecution set on foot at Nicomedia, Febr. 23d, and soon after in all other places.
The Persecution carried on with great severity in the East.
Diocletian and Herculius Maximian lay down the Empire. Galerius succeeds in the East, and continues the Persecution.

cell.p: Tho there be, that place the death of Constantius, and Constantines Succession, An. 305, yet we have chosen to follow the general computation, as built upon firmer and more certain grounds. Constan. M. Im. à Jul. 25.

row.cell: Constantine the Great succeeds his Father Constantius in the Empire; and Maxentius sets up for himself at Rome.
Licinius created Caesar by Galerius the Emperour.
A Convention of 270 schismatical Bishops and Traditores in Afric. vid. Aug. Epist. 48. ad Vincent.

cell.p: The Martyrdome of Pamphilus, Eusebius his dear friend.
A whole City in Phrygia suffers Martyrdome.

row.cell: About the end of this, or the beginning of the following year, the Persecution ceased in Palestine, and the Eastern Parts.

cell.p: Peter Bishop of Alexandria suffers Martyrdom Novemb. 24, or as others, 26.
Constantine beholds the vision of the Cross, and overcomes Maxentius.

p.hi: Towards the end of the year the Persecution ceases.

cell.p: Several Laws publisht by Constantine in favour of the Church, Clergy, and Christians.
Maximinus his last Edict in their behalf.
A Synod holden at Arles about the cause of Caecilian and Donatus.
The Councils of Ancyra and Neocaesarea holden this, or as others think the year following.
Several Priviledges and Immunities conferr'd by Constantine upon the Church.
About this time Arius began more openly to broach his heresy.
Licinius renews the Persecution against the Christians.
Crispus and Constantine junior created Caesars.
Peace made between Constantine and Licinius.

row.cell: Arius quits Alexandria, and flies into Palaestine, where he courts the Bishops to espouse his cause.

p.hi: The Christian Clergy exempted from public Offices.

row.cell: Great Reformation of manners made at Rome, as appears by several Laws in the Theodosian Code.

p.hi: A Law publisht for the observation of the Lords day.
Several others in favour of the Church, and against Pagan superstitions.

row.cell: A famine raging in Afric; a Rescript is sent to relieve the Poor out of the publick Exchequer.
Licinius finally routed by Constantine, whose Laws and Edicts he abrogated part this year, and part the next.
Hosius Bishop of Corduba dispatcht by Constantine with Letters to Alexandria, to compose the controversie between Alexander and Arius; but in vain.
The first general Council Assembled at Nice, wherein Arius and his Principles are confuted and condemn'd.

cell.p: Athanasius at the time of his advancement to that See, was probably in the 28th year current of his Age. See his Life, Sect. IV. Num. I. Athanasius chosen to the See of Alexandria.
Command given by Constantine for the erecting a stately Church at Jerusalem.
The death of the pious Helena mother to the Emperor Constantine.

p.hi: Christianity propagated in the Barbarous Countries.

row.cell: Eusebius and Theognis return from banishment (as Arius had done not long before) upon a pretended compliance with the Nicene faith.
The Arians and Meletians jointly accuse Athanasius to the Emperour, who discovers their malice.
Constantinople, begun two years since, finisht, and solemnly dedicated, May the 11th.
Macarius Bishop of Jerusalem dyes about this time, Maximus succeeds.
Athanasius commanded to clear himself of the death of Arsenius, enquires out the man.

cell.hi: Heathen superstitions abolisht, their Temples demolisht, or shut up, and the rents and revenues belonging to them taken away.

p.hi: A Law to free Widows, Orphans, the Poor and Infirm, from being compell'd to follow the Court in suits at Law.

cell.p: A Synod at Caesarea, whereat Athanasius refuses to appear.
A Synod holden by the Arians at Tyre in August and September, where they try, condemn and depose Athanasius.
The great Church at Jerusalem d • dicated.
The Arians at Constantinople charge Athanasius afresh; he is banisht by the Emperour to Triers.
Constantine the Great dyes May the 22d.
This was done, as appears from that Emperours Letter, June the 17th of that year.Athanasius releas'd from banishment by the younger Constantine.

row.cell: Nisibis miraculously defended against the siege of the King of Persia by the prayers of James Bishop of that place.
The Arians by Letters accuse Athanasius to the three Brother-Emperours.
The younger Constantine slain at Aquileia about the beginning of April

cell.p: The Synod at Antioch (call'd Synodus in Encaeniis) deposes Athanasius, and ordains Gregory the Cappadocian in his room.
Athanasius acquitted in a Synod at Rome.
A tumult at Constantinople about Paulus their Bishop.
The death of Paul the aged Hermit.
Some immunities granted by Constantius to the Clergy.

row.cell: The persecution against the Christians in Persia begun the foregoing year, carried on with great severity.
A second Synod holden at Antioch, wherein the large confession of faith is drawn up, and sent into the West.
A Synod assembled at Milan, which rejects the Message and Confession of the Eastern Bishops.
The Synod at Sardica, where the Eastern Bishops refuse to joyn with them of the West, notwithstanding which, Athanasius is heard, absolv'd, and restor'd.
This year dies Gregory Bishop of Alexandria, ten months after the Sardican Council.

cell.p: In a Synod at Sirmium, Photinus is depos'd, but retain'd by the People.
Athanasius being recall'd, in his return waits upon Constantius at Antioch.
The good Emperour Constans treacherously slain by Magnentius.
Athanasius is received with joy at Alexandria.
A Cross appears in the Heavens over Jerusalem at Whitsuntide.
A Synod holden at Sirmium aagainst Photinus.
Constantius's severe proceedings against the Jews in Palestine for their rebellion.
The death of Pope Julius April 12th. Liberius succeeds May the 8th.

row.cell: Athanasius condemned by the Arians in a Synod at Arles: the Popes own Legats drawn into the confederacy. Paulinus of Triers banisht for his refusal.
Gallus put to death. Julian comes to Athens, and there converses with Basil and Nazianzen.

At, or about the time of this Synod, Pope Liberius was banisht by the Emperour into Thrace.
A Council assembled by Constantius at Milan, wherein Athanasius is depos'd, and several Catholick Bishops banisht for not subscribing to it.

cell.p: George the Cappadocian in a Convention at Antioch is made Bishop of Alexandria: the cruel proceedings there at his arrival.

row.cell: An Arian Synod holden at Sirmium, which draws up a Confession of faith. Hosius compelled to subscribe it.
A new confession compos'd in another Synod at Sirmium, which Pope Liberius subscribing, is releas'd from banishment, and restor'd to his See.

cell.p: Tho Valesius and some others make but four Synods holden at Sirmium under Constantius, viz. Ann. 349, 351, 357, 358. (vid. Vales. Annot. in Sozom. p. 125.) yet very evident it is, that there was one more there this year, as is plain from the Confession there drawn up with the date of the Consuls affixt to it. Another confession drawn up at Sirmium May 22, with the date of the Consuls affixt to it.
A Council at Ariminum by the Western Bishops, another at the same time at Seleucia for the East.

row.cell: A Synodal convention of Arians at Constantinople Januar. 27th, wherein the several parties fall out. The Ariminum confession ratified.

cell.p: Constantius dies at Mopsucrenae in Cilicia, Octob. the 5th as some will; but as most others, Novemb. the 3d.
Julian begins openly to delare for Paganism.
Several methods set on foot by Julian to extirpate Christianity. He winters at Antioch.
Athanasius forct to fly from Alexandria.
Julian slain in the battel with the Persians.
Jovian succeeds, and favours Athanasius, and the Catholic side.

row.cell: Valens the Eastern Emperor begins to take part with the Arians against the Catholicks.
A Synod holden at Lampsacus by the Macedonian and Semiarian Party, who confirm the old Antioch confession of faith.
Valens shuts up the Churches belonging to the Novatians, and forces the Semiarians to subscribe the Arian confession.
Eustathius, Sylvanus and Theophilus appointed Legates by the Synod at Lampsacus, about this time take their journey, and impose upon Pope Damasus and the Western Bishops.

cell.p: The Macedonian Legates returning are received and restor'd by a Synod at Tyana.
Basil returns from his solitud • s, and is active at Caesarea.

row.cell: S. Hilary goes to Milan to confute Auxentius the Arian Bishop, returns home, and dies.

p.hi: The Catholicks severely persecuted by Valens.

cell.p: Basil made Bishop of Caesarea in Cappadocia.
S. Jerom arrives in the East, and places himself in the deserts of Syria.
Nazianzen about this time made Bishop of Sasima.

row.cell: The death of S. Athanasius. He is succeeded by Peter. Lucius made Bishop by the Arians. A grievous persecution thereupon at Alexandria.

cell.p: The Apollinarian haeresy condemn'd by Damasus in a Synod at Rome.
S. Chrysostom retires into the Monasteries near Antioch.
S. Ambrose made Bishop of Milan Decemb. 7.

row.cell: Post c. Gratiani III. & Equitii.

cell.p: S. Ambrose studies Theology under Simplician.
The death of Photinus the Haeresiarch.
The Gentiles greatly restrain'd at Rome.
Gratian forbids the Conventicles of Hereticks, and makes the places forfeitable to the Exchequer.
Valens afflicted by the invasion of the Goths, recalls the Catholiks from banishment.
Symmachus at Rome appears in favour of the Gentile-rites.
S. Basil dies; and not long after him, Ephraim Deacon of Edessa.
A Synod at Antioch for composing the distractions of the Eastern Church.

row.cell: Greg. Nazianzen comes to Constantinople and settles there. Jerom comes thither and studies under him.

cell.p: Theodosius baptiz'd at Thessalonica. He strenuously promotes and patronizes the Catholick faith.
The second general Council, holden at Constantinople, begun in May, and dissolved in July.
Nazianzen resigns the See of C. P. and retires.
A Synod assembled at Rome about the See of Antioch, at which were present Paulinus and Epiphanius.
Some part of the general Council reassembled at Constantinople.
S. Austin teaches Rhetoric at Rome.
Another Synod holden at Constantinople against Haereticks.
S. Austin sent to be Professor at Milan.
Symmachus presents his address in behalf of the Altar of victory, but is oppos'd by S. Ambrose.
Siricius made Bishop of Rome, January 12th.
S. Chrysostom made Priest at Antioch.
The death of Cyril Bishop of Jerusalem.
S. Jerom travels to Alexandria, and hears Didymus.
S. Ambrose sent upon an Embassy to Maximus.
The tumult at Antioch against the Imperial Statues, which others refer to the next year.
The death of Cynegius the Praefect, the great suppressor of Paganism in the East.
S. Austin is baptized at Milan by S. Ambrose.
Jovinian condemn'd by Pope Siricius, and the next year by a Synod at Milan.
The death of S. Gregory Nazianzen.

row.cell: The sedition at Thessalonica against the Emperors Officer. The miserable slaughter of Citizens there by the Emperors command.

cell.p: S. Austin ordain'd Presbyter at Hippo.
S. Jerom finisht his Catalogue of Ecclesiastic Writers.
Epiphanius writes to John of Jerusalem about the quarrel between them: and soon after Jerom writes to Pammachius adv. errores Joan. Hierosolym.
A Synod at Hippo for the reformation of discipline in the African Churches.
A convention of 310 Donatist Bishops at Bagaia in Numidia to allay the schism risen amongst them.
A Synod at Constantinople about the Bishoprick of Bostra.
S. Austin ordain'd Bishop, and made coadjutor with Valerius at Hippo.

p.hi: Severe Laws made against Heathens and Heretics.

cell.p: S. Ambrose by Letter instructs Fritigil Queen of the Marcomanni in the Christian faith.
S. Jerom writes his Epitaphium Nepotiani to Heliodorus.
S. Ambrose dies April the 4th, it being then the passion-week.
The death of Nectarius Bishop of Constantinople.
Chrysostom consecrated Bishop of Constantinople, Februar. 26.

row.cell: Chrysostom reforms his Clergy, opposes Gainas, Synodically examines the cause of Antonin Bishop of Ephesus, and goes into Asia about mid-winter.

cell.p: In a Synod of 70 Bishops at Ephesus, Chrysostom places Heraclides in that See, and deposes six Asian Bishops.
The Monks reinforce their complaints against Theophilus of Alexandria.
Two Councils at Carthage, one Provincial, May 27, the other general, Septemb. 13.

row.cell: Epiphanius comes to Constantinople to prosecute the Origenist-Monks, refuses communion with Chrysostom, returns back, and dies in the passage.
Theophilus summon'd to Constantinople. He condemns and deposes Chrysostom in the Synod at the Oak; who is banisht, but soon after recall'd, and acquitted in another Synod.

cell.p: Chrysostom again condemn'd, and by order from the Emperor banisht to Cucusus in Armenia, whither he arriv'd after 70 days journey.
Arsacius made Bishop of Constantinople, June 28th.
Chrysostom after a years stay at Cucusus, is remov'd to Arabissus.
Arsacius dies Novemb. 11th after he had sat somewhat more than one year and four months.

row.cell: After four months vacancy, Atticus a Monk is promoted to the See of Constantinople.
Chrysostom ordered to be remov'd to Pityus a Town in Pontus, but dies by the way at Comana Pontica, Septemb. 14th, and is buried there in the Tomb of S. Basiliscus the Martyr.
We have carried this Chronological Table seven years into the following Saeculum, to comply with the story of S. Chrysostom, whose death happen'd not till Anno 407.
